For rectal carcinoma located 5 cm from the anal verge, abdominal perineal resection (APR) is the gold standard surgical treatment.

questions.text: A patient had an RTA that caused crush injury. Within 3 days of the injury and post-amputation, crepitus was present and the wound was reddish brown. Identify the diagnosis: (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Gas gangrene 

 

Gas gangrene, caused by Clostridium bacteria, presents with rapid onset of severe pain, edema, and crepitus due to gas production in the tissues. The wound may appear reddish-brown or bronze-colored.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Necrotizing fasciitis: Necrotizing fasciitis is a rapidly progressing infection of the deeper layers of the skin and subcutaneous tissues, causing severe pain, skin discoloration, and systemic toxicity. However, it typically does not present with gas production.

 

Option C. Tetanus: Tetanus is caused by the bacterium Clostridium tetani and typically presents with muscle stiffness and spasms due to the neurotoxins produced by the bacteria. It does not involve crepitus or tissue gas.

 

Option D. Cellulitis: Cellulitis is a bacterial skin infection characterized by redness, swelling, warmth, and pain in the affected area. It does not typically involve gas production or crepitus.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Gas gangrene, characterized by rapid tissue destruction, gas production, and a reddish-brown appearance of the wound, should be promptly recognized and managed due to its potential for rapid progression and systemic complications.

choices.text: All zone 1 injury to be treated conservatively
Zone 3 injury whether blunt or penetrative should always be explored
Zone 2 injury with expanding hematoma should be treated surgically
Mattox maneuver is when the ascending colon is mobilized to the right to visualise the Aorta

questions.text: Identify the true statement regarding retroperitoneal trauma? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Zone 2 injury with expanding hematoma should be treated surgically

 

Zone 2 hematoma is seen in flank region and typically related to renal injury. Zone 2 hematomas may be conserved unless they are expanding, when surgery is indicated.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. All zone 1 injury to be treated conservatively: Zone 1 hematoma refers to central zone, where likely structures injured are abdominal aorta or IVC are injured. Since these are major vascular injuries, all zone 1 hematomas should be explored.

 

Option B. Zone 3 injury whether blunt or penetrative should always be explored: Zone 3 refers to the pelvis region, and injuries in this area Should be managed conservatively with pelvic binder or external fixator. Exploration in these areas is dangerous and should be avoided whenever possible.

 

Option D. Mattox maneuver is when the ascending colon is mobilized to the right to visualise the Aorta: The Mattox maneuver is a surgical technique used during emergency laparotomies to visualize the abdominal aorta. It involves mobilizing the left sided abdominal viscera medially, which allows for better visualization of the retroperitoneum and the aorta. This maneuver can be useful in cases of trauma or other emergency situations where visualization of the aorta is necessary.

questions.text: A 4-week-old child with a history of vomiting undergoes imaging as shown. What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans.  A) Congenital Pyloric Stenosis


The correct diagnosis is Congenital Pyloric Stenosis. This condition typically presents in infants between 3-6 weeks of age with symptoms of projectile, non-bilious vomiting, and a palpable olive-shaped mass in the upper abdomen. The ultrasound image shows a thickened pylorus muscle and a distended stomach, which are characteristic findings of pyloric stenosis. The hypertrophied pyloric muscle obstructs gastric emptying, leading to the clinical symptoms observed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Duodenal Atresia: Duodenal atresia is a congenital condition usually presenting at birth with bilious vomiting due to a blockage in the duodenum. It is often associated with a “double bubble” sign on imaging. The condition does not fit the presentation of a 4-week-old with the typical findings seen in the ultrasound provided.

 

Option C. Annular Pancreas: Annular pancreas is a congenital anomaly where the pancreas encircles the duodenum, potentially causing obstruction. It usually presents with symptoms soon after birth, similar to duodenal atresia, including bilious vomiting. This condition would not show the thickened pylorus seen in the ultrasound provided.

 

Option D. Volvulus: Volvulus, often associated with malrotation of the midgut, can present at any age, including the newborn period or later in life. It typically presents with bilious vomiting, abdominal distension, and sometimes acute abdominal pain. The ultrasound findings here do not indicate the twisted bowel loops characteristic of volvulus but rather show a thickened pyloric muscle.

 

Educational Objective:


Congenital Pyloric Stenosis is characterized by the hypertrophy of the pylorus muscle, leading to projectile, non-bilious vomiting in infants aged 3-6 weeks. Ultrasound is diagnostic, showing a thickened pyloric muscle and a distended stomach, distinguishing it from other causes of vomiting in infancy.

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient presented with neck swelling as shown. The swelling moves with deglutition and tongue protrusion. What is your diagnosis?  (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Thyroglossal cyst

 

Among the given options, thyroglossal cyst is the only neck swelling which is midline, moves with deglutition and tongue protrusion. This is because the thyroid gland is fixed to the hyoid.

 

Thyroglossal cysts are cystic swellings that form from the remnants of the thyroglossal duct, which is a duct that connects the developing thyroid gland to the tongue during embryonic development. These cysts often move with deglutition or tongue protrusion and are typically located in the midline of the neck, as seen in the provided image.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Branchial cyst: Branchial cysts are typically located along the anterior border of the sternocleidomastoid muscle (upper and middle third) and do not move with deglutition. They are congenital and arise from remnants of branchial arches.

 

 

Option B. Cystic hygroma: Cystic hygromas are usually found in the neck and are also congenital, usually in posterior triangle. They are caused by lymphatic malformation and do not typically move with deglutition.

 

 

Option D. Cervical lymphadenopathy: Cervical lymphadenopathy refers to enlarged lymph nodes in the neck. While lymph nodes can sometimes be palpable in the neck, they do not usually move with deglutition and are not typically cystic in nature.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Other neck swellings that move with deglutition are:

 

  • Thyroid swellings
  • Subhyoid bursitis
  • Dermoid cysts attached to the hyoid bone

 

However, amongst these only the thyroglossal cyst moves with tongue protrusion. This occurs because the duct extends from the foramen caecum of tongue to the isthmus of the gland.

 

Sistrunk's operation is the procedure performed to excise the cyst and prevent a recurrence. It involves excision of the whole thyroglossal tract, along with removal of the body of the hyoid bone, and suprahyoid tract through the tongue base to the vallecula at the site of the primitive foramen caecum along with the core of tissue on either side.

choices.text: Junction of upper and middle third of the sternomastoid muscle
Junction of middle and lower third of the sternomastoid muscle
Between the two heads of the sternomastoid muscle

questions.text: Which of these is the most common site of a branchial cyst? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Junction of upper and middle third of the sternomastoid muscle

Explanation:

 

The typical location for a branchial cyst is at the anterior border of the junction between the upper and middle third of the sternomastoid muscle. Branchial cysts are developmental anomalies that arise from the remnants of the second branchial cleft. They are lined by squamous epithelium and contain thick, cloudy fluid that often includes cholesterol crystals. This location is key for identifying and diagnosing branchial cysts.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Junction of middle and lower third of the sternomastoid muscle: This location is typically associated with the external opening of a branchial fistula, not a branchial cyst.

 

Option C. Middle of the sternomastoid muscle: This is not the usual site for branchial cysts. Branchial cysts are more commonly found at the anterior border of the upper and middle third junction.

 

Option D. Between the two heads of the sternomastoid muscle: This area is not associated with the typical location of branchial cysts. The cysts are more commonly found anterior to the sternomastoid muscle.

 

Additional Information on Branchial Cysts:

  • Origin: Congenital or acquired remnants of the second branchial cleft.
  • Lining: Squamous epithelium.
  • Contents: Thick, cloudy fluid with cholesterol crystals, sometimes clear fluid making the cyst soft and shiny.
  • Branchial Fistula: The external opening of a branchial fistula is at the junction of the middle and lower third of the anterior border of the sternocleidomastoid.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most common site for a branchial cyst is at the anterior border of the junction between the upper and middle third of the sternomastoid muscle.

questions.text: After parotid surgery, the patient is found to have weakness of the lower lip on the ipsilateral side. Which of these injuries is likely to produce this? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cervical branch of facial nerve

 

In this scenario, the patient has undergone parotid surgery and subsequently developed weakness of the lower lip on the same side as the surgery (ipsilateral). This kind of symptom indicates a nerve injury.

 

  • Facial Nerve Branches: The facial nerve (cranial nerve VII) is responsible for motor control of the muscles of facial expression. It divides into several branches after it exits the stylomastoid foramen, including the temporal, zygomatic, buccal, mandibular (marginal mandibular), and cervical branches.
  • Cervical Branch: The cervical branch of the facial nerve, along with the marginal mandibular branch, supplies the muscles of the lower face, including those involved in the movement of the lower lip. An injury to the cervical branch could result in weakness of the lower lip, which is consistent with the patient's presentation.
  • Marginal Mandibular Branch: Although the marginal mandibular branch is primarily responsible for the lower lip, in cases where this specific branch is not listed as an option, the cervical branch is the closest and most accurate choice because it is part of the lower division of the facial nerve that supplies the lower lip muscles.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Main trunk of the facial nerve: Injury to the main trunk of the facial nerve would likely cause more extensive symptoms, including the inability to close the eye (Bell's phenomenon), loss of forehead wrinkling, and other signs of lower motor neuron facial paralysis, which are not mentioned in this case. Therefore, this option is less likely.

 

Option B. Temporal branch of the facial nerve: The temporal branch of the facial nerve innervates muscles in the upper face, such as those involved in raising the eyebrows and closing the eyelids. It does not affect the lower lip, making this option incorrect.

 

Option D. Parotid duct: Injury to the parotid duct would result in issues related to salivation, such as a salivary fistula, but it would not cause motor weakness of the lower lip. This option is also incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Weakness of the lower lip after parotid surgery is most likely due to injury to the cervical branch of the facial nerve. The marginal mandibular branch is the most specific, but if not listed, the cervical branch is the closest correct option

choices.text: Parasympathetic - bladder dysfunction and retrograde ejaculation.
Sympathetic - retrograde ejaculation and bladder dysfunction.
Sympathetic - Impotence and loss of cutaneous sensation in perineal region

questions.text: Identify the most common neurological complication following ligation of the Inferior mesenteric artery during abdominoperineal resection for rectal carcinoma? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Sympathetic - retrograde ejaculation and bladder dysfunction.

 

  • An abdominoperineal resection involves the removal of the left colon, pelvic floor, rectum, and anal canal.
  •  It is typically indicated for patients with operable low rectal carcinomas located within 5 cm of the anal verge.
  • The sympathetic innervation of the rectum originates from L1 – L3 spinal nerves, which form the superior hypogastric plexus.  
  • At the level of the sacral promontory, these nerves divide into the left and right hypogastric nerves, traveling on both sides of the pelvis.
  • These nerves supply the rectum and send branches to supply the genitourinary system anteriorly.
  • During pelvic surgeries, it is crucial to be aware of these nerves to avoid injuring them.
  • High ligation of the inferior mesenteric artery (IMA) near the sacral promontory may injure the superior hypogastric nerves, leading to sympathetic dysfunction.
  • This dysfunction is characterized by retrograde ejaculation and bladder dysfunction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Parasympathetic - bladder dysfunction and retrograde ejaculation: Parasympathetic nerves are less likely to be affected by the ligation of the IMA as their pathways are different. Parasympathetic innervation primarily involves the pelvic splanchnic nerves (S2-S4), which are not typically disrupted in this procedure.

 

Option B. Sympathetic - bladder dysfunction and impotence: While bladder dysfunction is a possible consequence of sympathetic nerve damage, impotence is not the most common result of injury to the sympathetic nerves. The more typical outcome includes retrograde ejaculation.

 

Option D. Sympathetic - Impotence and loss of cutaneous sensation in perineal region: Loss of cutaneous sensation in the perineal region would more likely result from damage to the pudendal nerve, not the sympathetic nerves. Impotence can occur but is less specific compared to retrograde ejaculation in the context of IMA ligation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • During abdominoperineal resection for rectal carcinoma, ligation of the inferior mesenteric artery may lead to sympathetic nerve damage, particularly the superior hypogastric plexus.
  • This can result in neurological complications such as retrograde ejaculation and bladder dysfunction.

choices.text: Soft tissue calcification in the neck

questions.text: A toddler was found playing alone and was brought to the emergency department with complaints of difficulty in swallowing for the past few hours. An X-ray was performed, and the image revealed as shown in AP view. What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Foreign body in the esophagus

 

  • A child presenting with difficulty in swallowing and the given X-ray suggest a foreign body lodged in the esophagus, most likely a coin or disc battery.
  • Anteroposterior (AP) and lateral views of the chest and neck X-rays were taken, and the flat surface of the coin in the esophagus is seen on the AP view, while the edge is seen on the lateral view.
  • Initial symptoms of esophageal foreign body ingestion include choking, gagging, and coughing, followed by excessive salivation, dysphagia, food refusal, vomiting, or pain in the neck and throat.
  • Respiratory symptoms such as stridor, wheezing, cyanosis, or dyspnea may also be seen.
  • Correct. If an object gets lodged in the esophagus, it can cause difficulty swallowing, pain, and drooling. The scenario presented indicates an X-ray showing a radiopaque foreign body (likely a coin or disc battery) in the esophagus, which is consistent with the child's symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Foreign body in the trachea: When a foreign body is stuck in the trachea, it is a life-threatening situation as it can block airflow. Symptoms would typically include coughing, choking, wheezing, and difficulty breathing. The flat surface would be better seen in the lateral view.

 

Option C. Artifact: An artifact in radiology refers to any distortion or error in the image that is not present in the patient. Artifacts can be due to the equipment, the patient's movement, or other factors.

 

Option D. Soft tissue calcification in the neck: This refers to the presence of calcified deposits in the soft tissues of the neck. These can be due to various reasons, such as long-standing inflammation, tumors, or other diseases. However, the presentation of acute difficulty in swallowing and the X-ray findings make this option unlikely.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In cases of pediatric ingestion of foreign bodies, the esophagus is a common site where objects can become lodged.
  • Radiographic evaluation typically shows a foreign body in the esophagus with a flat surface seen on the AP view and the edge on the lateral view.
  •  Immediate recognition and appropriate intervention are crucial to prevent complications.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presented to the emergency department after a motor vehicle accident. He was the driver of the car, and upon impact, he had hit his abdomen against the steering wheel. Upon examination, the patient was conscious but complained of severe abdominal pain and tenderness upon palpation. The physician noted bruising and swelling in the abdominal area. Further evaluation revealed the evisceration of omentum, which was protruding through a laceration in the abdominal wall. What would be the best management of the same? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Emergency laparotomy

 

  • In the context of penetrating trauma, especially with evisceration (protrusion of internal tissues or organs through a wound), an emergency laparotomy becomes the procedure of choice to address any potential life-threatening injuries, stop bleeding, and repair damaged structures.
  • Evisceration is an indicator of full-thickness injury to the abdominal wall and potential underlying organ damage.

 

Indications for emergency laparotomy in penetrating trauma include:

 

  • Unstable patient
  • Features of peritonitis
  • Evisceration
  • Gunshot wounds

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Observation: Observation alone in this scenario would delay necessary intervention and could worsen the patient's outcome. Immediate surgical intervention is necessary to manage the evisceration and associated internal injuries.

 

Option C. Intravenous hydration: While IV hydration might be a part of the supportive care for a trauma patient, it is not the primary treatment for an evisceration injury. The priority would be to address the traumatic injury directly through surgery.

 

Option D. Wait and watch: This approach, like observation, is passive and is not suitable for traumatic injuries that are obviously severe, like evisceration. Delay in surgical intervention could lead to complications and worsen the patient's prognosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Evisceration in the context of trauma is a surgical emergency that requires immediate laparotomy to address potential internal injuries, control bleeding, and repair the damage.
  • Prompt surgical intervention is crucial to prevent complications and improve patient outcomes.

questions.text: A 80-year-old male patient presents with a PSA level of 7 ng/mL and a small tumor focus in prostate with a Gleason score of 6, what would be the most appropriate course of action for management?(NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Active surveillance

 

The given clinical vignette is suggestive of a diagnosis of low-risk prostatic carcinoma. The most likely management for this patient would be active surveillance only.

  • Active surveillance is a management approach used for prostate cancer with specific criteria.
  • Criteria for active surveillance include Gleason score 6, early-stage disease (T1), small volume disease on biopsy, age > 70 years and low PSA (<10 ng/mL).
  • Active surveillance protocols include regular digital rectal examination and PSA monitoring every 3 to 6 months, with TRUS-guided prostate biopsies every 1 to 3 years.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Radical prostatectomy: This surgical procedure involves removing the entire prostate gland. It is often considered for prostate cancer treatment, especially for younger, healthier patients or those with more aggressive forms of the disease.

 

Option B. External beam radiation: This treatment involves using targeted radiation beams to kill cancer cells. It can be considered for prostate cancer, particularly when surgery is not an option. The choice between radiation therapy and active surveillance depends on various factors, including the patient's age, overall health, and the stage and aggressiveness of the cancer.

 

Option C. Brachytherapy: Brachytherapy is a form of radiation therapy where radioactive seeds or sources are placed directly into or near the tumor. It's a localized treatment and can be used for low to intermediate-risk prostate cancer. Again, the decision to use brachytherapy depends on several factors, including the patient's overall health and the characteristics of the cancer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Active surveillance is an appropriate management strategy for older patients with low-risk prostate cancer, characterized by a Gleason score of 6, early-stage disease, small tumor volume, and low PSA levels.
  • This approach minimizes unnecessary treatments and associated side effects, focusing on regular monitoring to detect any changes in the cancer's status.

questions.text: You are doing an emergency laparotomy for a case of intestinal obstruction. Which organ will be first visualized to know if this is a case of small bowel or large bowel obstruction? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cecum

 

The caecum is a pouch-like structure at the beginning of the colon. Visualizing the caecum first would indicate that the obstruction likely involves the large bowel if it is distended, helping to differentiate it from a small bowel obstruction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The cecum is the first organ to be visualized to differentiate between small and large bowel obstruction in cases of intestinal obstruction.

 

Distension of the cecum will confirm large bowel involvement, while collapsed cecum implies small bowel obstruction.

 

Identifying a collapsed distal segment of the large bowel and its sequential proximal assessment leads to the identification of the cause.

choices.text: Upper GI endoscopy and 24-hour PH monitoring

questions.text: A 45-year-old man comes to the clinic with a complaint of difficulty in swallowing both solids and liquids for the last eight months. A barium swallow test has been conducted, and the results are available for review. What further investigations are required for this patient? (AIIMS NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Upper GI endoscopy & Manometry

 

The given scenario of long standing dysphagia in a 45 year old, with barium swallow showing smooth tapering is suggestive of achalasia. Next investigations would be upper GI endoscopy (to rule of cancer) and esophageal manometry (IOC).

 

  • Upper GI endoscopy: This procedure involves a visual examination of the esophagus, allowing the physician to see any obstructions, lesions, or abnormalities that could be causing dysphagia like cancer
  • Manometry: Manometry measures the pressures and coordinated muscle contractions of the esophagus. It's particularly helpful for conditions like achalasia, where there's an absence of normal esophageal peristalsis and increased lower esophageal sphincter tone.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Upper GI endoscopy & PET scan: While a PET scan can identify metabolic activity and might be useful in detecting metastasis, it isn't a first-line test for dysphagia. The primary concern with dysphagia is often mechanical or functional obstruction, which a PET scan wouldn't directly address.

 

Option C. Upper GI endoscopy & CECT: CECT (Contrast-Enhanced Computed Tomography) can provide images of the esophagus, but it is not the primary modality for evaluating dysphagia. While it can identify masses or structural issues, it doesn't offer functional insights like manometry.

 

Option D. Upper GI endoscopy and 24-hour PH monitoring: 24-hour pH monitoring assesses the acidity in the esophagus over 24 hours. While it can be valuable for diagnosing conditions like GERD, it's not the primary investigation for dysphagia unless reflux symptoms are predominant

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Achalasia is a disorder of the esophagus characterized by absent peristalsis and impaired relaxation of the LES.
  • Manometry is the most sensitive test to diagnose achalasia and can identify early disease before esophageal dilatation and food retention.
  • The diagnostic criteria for achalasia with manometry are impaired LES relaxation, absent peristalsis, and elevated LES pressure. Subtypes are classified according to Chicago classification as Type 1 (classical), Type 2 (pan-esophageal pressurisation) and type 3 (Spastic).
  • Endoscopy can rule out pseudo achalasia/carcinoma.

questions.text: A 68-year-old female is admitted to the hospital with complaints of vomiting and abdominal distention. A nasogastric (NG) tube is inserted to decompress the stomach. However, the patient remains conscious and alert during the procedure. What is the best position to place the patient in during the insertion of the NG tube? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Sitting with neck flexion

 

This is the best position for a conscious patient during Ryle's tube insertion. Sitting allows for better alignment of the upper gastrointestinal tract, making it easier to guide the tube through the esophagus and into the stomach. Neck flexion helps align the crico-pharynx with the Ryle’s tube, reducing faulty tracheal insertion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The best position for a conscious patient to be in during the insertion of Ryle's tube is sitting with neck flexion.

 

Confirmation of the correct position of RT is done by:

 

  • Auscultation in the epigastric area while injecting a bolus of air
  • Aspiration of gastric contents
  • X-ray chest + upper abdomen

 

The approximate length of the Ryle’s tube is 120-125 cm. There are 4 markings on the tube which indicates the traversing of the tube through various parts of the stomach

 

  1. 40 cm - Tube has traversed cardia of the stomach
  2. 50 cm - Tube has traversed body of the stomach
  3. 60 cm - Tube has traversed pylorus
  4. 70 cm - Tube has traversed duodenum

 

The length of tube to be inserted is calculated by measuring the distance between nose-tip of ear lobule-xiphoid (N-E-X rule).

questions.text: A 28-year-old patient was brought to the casualty with high fever and pain in abdomen. He had a history of bloody diarrhea for several months. There was no past history of long-term medications and previous surgeries. The abdominal X-ray image obtained is shown below. What is the most probable diagnosis? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Toxic megacolon

 

The probable diagnosis is toxic megacolon.

 

Toxic megacolon is a severe condition characterized by acute colonic distension and systemic toxicity. It is often associated with inflammatory bowel disease, such as ulcerative colitis. Patients with toxic megacolon can present with high fever, abdominal pain, and a history of bloody diarrhea, which aligns with the patient's symptoms in this case. The abdominal X-ray shows transverse colonic dilation > 6 cm, which is a characteristic finding in toxic megacolon.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Volvulus: Volvulus is a condition in which a portion of the bowel twists on itself, leading to obstruction and ischemia. While it can cause abdominal pain, it typically does not present with the same systemic symptoms seen in toxic megacolon.

 

Option C. Ogilvie syndrome: Ogilvie syndrome, also known as acute colonic pseudo-obstruction, is characterized by marked colonic dilation without a mechanical obstruction. It can cause abdominal pain and distension but does not typically present with a history of bloody diarrhea.

 

Option D. Pneumatosis intestinalis: Pneumatosis intestinalis refers to the presence of gas within the wall of the intestine. While it can be seen on imaging studies, it is not a specific diagnosis and does not explain the patient's symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The X-ray image shows a dilated loop of the transverse colon > 6 cm. The history of bloody diarrhea and loss of haustrations are suggestive of ulcerative colitis. Sudden onset of fever, abdominal pain with dilated loops of bowel in a patient with ulcerative colitis point towards toxic megacolon.

 

A plain abdominal X-ray film can indicate the severity of ulcerative colitis in the acute setting and is especially valuable in demonstrating the development of toxic megacolon. The next step would be to perform a CECT abdomen to assess status of bowel and urgent exploration may be needed if ischemia or perforation is seen.

questions.text: Mrs. Johnson is a 60-year-old woman who underwent a Whipple's procedure for pancreatic cancer three weeks ago. She developed a fever and abdominal pain, and her surgeon suspected a postoperative complication. Which of the following complications causes maximum malnutrition? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Duodenal fistula

 

  • Among the given conditions, maximum malnutrition is caused by duodenal fistulas.
  • Enterocutaneous fistulas are classified based on their location and volume of daily output.
  • Proximal fistulas have higher output and are associated with greater fluid, electrolyte, and digestive capacity loss.
  • Distal fistulas have lower output and are easier to manage, with a higher likelihood of spontaneous closure.
  • Duodenal fistulas receive an additional 1 to 2 liters of enzymes, electrolytes, and water from the pancreatic and bile ducts, making them more susceptible to electrolyte imbalances than gastric fistulas.
  • The management of enterocutaneous fistulas follows the SNAP principles:
    • S: Sepsis elimination and skin protection
    • N: A period of parenteral nutrition may be required
    • A: Anatomical assessment
    • P: Definitive planned surgery.

 

A duodenal fistula involves a connection between the duodenum (the first part of the small intestine) and an unintended location, such as the abdominal cavity. This can result in severe malnutrition because the duodenum is a critical site for nutrient absorption in the digestive process. A duodenal fistula can lead to the loss of digestive juices and nutrients, significantly impacting a patient's nutritional status.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pancreatic fistula: A pancreatic fistula is a complication where pancreatic fluids leak from the surgical site. While it can lead to malnutrition due to the loss of digestive enzymes, it is not typically as severe as a duodenal fistula in causing malnutrition.

 

Option C. Distal ileal fistula: While a distal ileal fistula can disrupt nutrient absorption to some extent, it is not as critical as a duodenal fistula in terms of causing maximum malnutrition. The ileum is further down the small intestine, and its role in nutrient absorption is not as central as that of the duodenum.

 

Option D. Colonic fistula: A colonic fistula may lead to the loss of stool and fluids but is not primarily responsible for causing severe malnutrition in the same way as a duodenal fistula. The colon's main function is to absorb water and electrolytes, not nutrients.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A duodenal fistula (option B) is the postoperative complication that can cause maximum malnutrition due to its disruption of nutrient absorption in the critical site of the digestive process, the duodenum.

questions.text: Locally advanced breast cancer can be defined as all except? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tumor more than 4 cm

 

While a tumor size larger than 4 cm is indicative of a relatively large tumor, it alone does not define locally advanced breast cancer. Locally advanced breast cancer typically involves not only tumor size but also the extent of its spread to nearby structures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Inflammatory breast cancer: Inflammatory breast cancer is an aggressive subtype of breast cancer characterized by redness, swelling, and warmth in the breast. It is considered an advanced stage of breast cancer.

 

Option C. Chest wall involvement: Locally advanced breast cancer is often defined by its involvement of the chest wall. This means that the cancer has spread beyond the breast tissue and may affect the underlying muscles and structures of the chest wall.

 

Option D. Skin involvement: Skin involvement, such as changes in the appearance of the skin over the breast like peau’d orange or ulceration, can be a feature of locally advanced breast cancer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tumor more than 5 cm, not 4 is classified as LABC.

 

Locally advanced breast cancer (LABC) includes: (Mnemonic – CUBE N2)

 

C - Chest wall invasion

 

U - Ulceration of skin

 

B - Both (chest wall invasion and ulceration of skin)

 

E - E(I)nflammatory carcinoma

 

N2 - fixed axillary lymph nodes

questions.text: A 28-year-old male presents to the emergency department with multiple stab injuries to the chest. On examination, there is reduced chest movement on the right side and tracheal deviation to the left side. Additionally, the neck veins are distended. What is the next best step in the management of this patient? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Needle thoracocentesis

 

Patient with stab to chest with reduced chest movement on right, mediastinal shift to left with distended neck veins is suffering from tension pneumothorax. Next step is placement of wide bore needle in triangle of safety to decompress the pneumothorax, followed by ICD insertion.

 

This is the correct answer. Needle thoracocentesis is the next best step in the management of the patient with tension pneumothorax. It is a procedure that involves inserting a needle into the pleural space to aspirate the air or fluid. It is performed initially to decompress the tension pneumothorax in the triangle of safety (between Pect. Major anteriorly, Latissimus dorsi posteriorly, 5th intercostal space inferiorly).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Emergency room thoracotomy: This is not the next best step in the management of the patient with tension pneumothorax. Resuscitative thoracotomy is an emergency surgical procedure that is performed in the presence of cardiac arrest due to penetrating chest trauma.

 

Option B. ICD placement: This is not the next best step in the management of the patient with tension pneumothorax. An ICD (intercostal drainage) is a tube inserted into the pleural space to drain the air or fluid. ICD placement is the definitive management of tension pneumothorax but is not the next step in the management.

 

Option D. Finger thoracotomy: This is not the next best step in the management of the patient with tension pneumothorax. Finger thoracotomy is an alternative approach when needle decompression fails or is not possible. It involves making a small incision in the chest wall and using the finger to manually decompress the pneumothorax. However, needle decompression should be attempted first before considering finger thoracostomy.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female presents with a breast condition as demonstrated in the image below. This condition is due to invasion of? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Dermal lymphatics

 

The image demonstrates a peau d'orange (orange peel) appearance of the breast, which occurs due to the blockade of superficial dermal lymphatics by tumor invasion. This blockage causes edema in the breast, making the sweat glands and hair follicles more prominent and resulting in the typical orange peel appearance. Additionally, infiltration of the ligaments of Cooper can result in dimpling of the skin.

 

  • Dermal lymphatics: Blockade by tumor invasion leads to edema, causing the peau d'orange appearance.
  • Deep lymphatics: Involvement would likely lead to different clinical manifestations, not specifically the peau d'orange appearance.
  • Superficial veins: Blockage would more likely result in visible vein distention or other vascular issues rather than the peau d'orange appearance.
  • Deep veins: Similar to deep lymphatics, involvement would not specifically cause the characteristic peau d'orange appearance.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Deep lymphatics: Incorrect. While the deep lymphatics can be involved in breast cancer spread, they are not specifically responsible for the peau d'orange appearance.

 

Option C. Superficial veins: Incorrect. Blockage or involvement of superficial veins would result in different symptoms, such as vein distention, and is not typically associated with the peau d'orange appearance.

 

Option D. Deep veins: Incorrect. Similar to deep lymphatics, involvement of deep veins would not specifically cause the characteristic peau d'orange appearance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The peau d'orange appearance of the breast is due to blockage of the superficial dermal lymphatics by tumor invasion, leading to edema and the characteristic skin changes.
